pageProps.contentHtml:
Banach spaces

Recall that a metric space is separable if it contains a countable dense subset.

  1. Prove that ℓ1(N)\ell^1\p{\N}ℓ1(N) and ℓ2(N)\ell^2\p{\N}ℓ2(N) are separable Banach spaces but ℓ∞(N)\ell^\infty\p{\N}ℓ∞(N) is not.
  2. Prove that there exists no linear bounded surjective map T ⁣:ℓ2(N)→ℓ1(N)\func{T}{\ell^2\p{\N}}{\ell^1\p{\N}}T:ℓ2(N)→ℓ1(N).
Solution.

  1. Let D⊆CD \subseteq \CD⊆C be a countable, dense set (e.g., rational linear combinations of 111 and iii). Then

    A={{an}n∣an∈D and an≠0 for only finitely many terms}A = \set{\set{a_n}_n \mid a_n \in D \text{ and } a_n \neq 0 \text{ for only finitely many terms}}A={{an​}n​∣an​∈D and an​=0 for only finitely many terms}

    is a countable union of countable sets, hence countable itself. We will show that AAA is dense in both ℓ1(N)\ell^1\p{\N}ℓ1(N) and ℓ2(N)\ell^2\p{\N}ℓ2(N): let p∈{1,2}p \in \set{1, 2}p∈{1,2}, {xn}n∈ℓp(N)\set{x_n}_n \in \ell^p\p{\N}{xn​}n​∈ℓp(N), and ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0. Then there exists N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that

    ∑n=N+1∞∣xn∣p<ε.\sum_{n=N+1}^\infty \abs{x_n}^p < \epsilon.n=N+1∑∞​∣xn​∣p<ε.

    For each 1≤n≤N1 \leq n \leq N1≤n≤N, there exists qnq_nqn​ such that ∣xn−qn∣p<εN\abs{x_n - q_n}^p < \frac{\epsilon}{N}∣xn​−qn​∣p<Nε​, by density. Set qn=0q_n = 0qn​=0 for n>Nn > Nn>N which means {qn}n∈A\set{q_n}_n \in A{qn​}n​∈A. Then

    ∑n=1∞∣xn−qn∣p=∑n=1N∣xn−qn∣p+∑n=N+1∞∣xn−qn∣p≤∑n=1NεN+∑n=N+1∞∣xn∣p≤2ε,\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \abs{x_n - q_n}^p &= \sum_{n=1}^N \abs{x_n - q_n}^p + \sum_{n=N+1}^\infty \abs{x_n - q_n}^p \\ &\leq \sum_{n=1}^N \frac{\epsilon}{N} + \sum_{n=N+1}^\infty \abs{x_n}^p \\ &\leq 2\epsilon, \end{aligned}n=1∑∞​∣xn​−qn​∣p​=n=1∑N​∣xn​−qn​∣p+n=N+1∑∞​∣xn​−qn​∣p≤n=1∑N​Nε​+n=N+1∑∞​∣xn​∣p≤2ε,​

    so AAA is dense in both ℓ1(N)\ell^1\p{\N}ℓ1(N) and ℓ2(N)\ell^2\p{\N}ℓ2(N).

    To show that ℓ∞(N)\ell^\infty\p{\N}ℓ∞(N) is not separable, consider the set AAA of infinite binary strings, i.e., {xn}n\set{x_n}_n{xn​}n​ so that xn∈{0,1}x_n \in \set{0, 1}xn​∈{0,1} for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1. Certainly A⊆ℓ∞(N)A \subseteq \ell^\infty\p{\N}A⊆ℓ∞(N), and if x≠yx \neq yx=y are elements of AAA, there exists some n0n_0n0​ so that xn0≠yn0x_{n_0} \neq y_{n_0}xn0​​=yn0​​. Hence, ∥xn0−yn0∥ℓ∞=1\norm{x_{n_0} - y_{n_0}}_{\ell^\infty} = 1∥xn0​​−yn0​​∥ℓ∞​=1.

    Suppose {an}n\set{a_n}_n{an​}n​ is dense in ℓ∞(N)\ell^\infty\p{\N}ℓ∞(N). Then for each x∈Ax \in Ax∈A, there exists an(x)a_{n\p{x}}an(x)​ such that ∥an(x)−x∥ℓ∞<12\norm{a_{n\p{x}} - x}_{\ell^\infty} < \frac{1}{2}∥∥​an(x)​−x∥∥​ℓ∞​<21​. But x↦n(x)x \mapsto n\p{x}x↦n(x) is an injective function from an uncountable set to a countable one, which is impossible. Thus, ℓ∞\ell^\inftyℓ∞ is not separable.

  2. We first prove the following lemma: if T ⁣:X→Y\func{T}{X}{Y}T:X→Y is a continuous linear map between Banach spaces, then T†T^\daggerT† is injective if and only if the range of TTT is dense in YYY, where T†T^\daggerT† is the transpose of TTT.

    Suppose T†T^\daggerT† is injective, but the range of TTT is not dense. Let M=range⁡T‾M = \cl{\range{T}}M=rangeT​, which is not all of YYY by assumption. Hence, there exists some y∈Y∖My \in Y \setminus My∈Y∖M with distance δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 away from MMM. By Hahn-Banach, there exists f∈Y∗f \in Y^*f∈Y∗ such that f(x)=0f\p{x} = 0f(x)=0 on MMM and f(y)=δf\p{y} = \deltaf(y)=δ. Thus, T†(f)=f∘T∈X∗T^\dagger\p{f} = f \circ T \in X^*T†(f)=f∘T∈X∗, but by construction f(T(x))=0f\p{T\p{x}} = 0f(T(x))=0 for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X. Hence, T†(f)=0T^\dagger\p{f} = 0T†(f)=0, but f≠0f \neq 0f=0, a contradiction.

    Conversely, suppose range⁡T\range{T}rangeT is dense in YYY, and suppose f∈Y∗f \in Y^*f∈Y∗ is such that T†(f)=0T^\dagger\p{f} = 0T†(f)=0. Since f∘T=T†(f)f \circ T = T^\dagger\p{f}f∘T=T†(f) and range⁡T\range{T}rangeT is dense, it follows that f(y)=0f\p{y} = 0f(y)=0 for any y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y, by continuity, so f=0f = 0f=0 and hence T†T^\daggerT† is injective.

    In our problem, our TTT is surjective, in particular dense in ℓ1(N)\ell^1\p{\N}ℓ1(N). Thus, T† ⁣:ℓ∞(N)→ℓ2(N)\func{T^\dagger}{\ell^\infty\p{\N}}{\ell^2\p{\N}}T†:ℓ∞(N)→ℓ2(N) is an injective bounded linear map, so T†T^\daggerT† is an isomorphism ℓ∞(N)→T†(ℓ2(N))\ell^\infty\p{\N} \to T^\dagger\p{\ell^2\p{\N}}ℓ∞(N)→T†(ℓ2(N)), and so we have a continuous linear map T†(ℓ2(N))→ℓ∞(N)T^\dagger\p{\ell^2\p{\N}} \to \ell^\infty\p{\N}T†(ℓ2(N))→ℓ∞(N). But ℓ2(N)\ell^2\p{\N}ℓ2(N) is separable, which would imply by continuity that ℓ∞(N)\ell^\infty\p{\N}ℓ∞(N) is also separable, a contradiction. Hence, no continuous surjection could have existed to begin with, which completes the proof.
